SPREAD

Date

Place

Name

500BCE

Northern India

Buddhism Founding

400BCE

Northern India

Buddhism has spread through North India, along the foothills of the Himalayas.

320BCE

Northern India

Buddhism split (West is original (Sthaviravada), east is Mahasamghika)

250BCE

North & Central India

Buddhism has worked its way south, east is S, south is M.

230BCE

Pakistan and Sri Lanka

S split and V (Vibhajjavada) in northern Pakistan and Sri Lanka.

10CE

Afghanistan1

Paki V has made its way northwards, got to Silk Road

100CE

Kyrgyzstan

V has made its way to Kyrgyzstan

150CE

Kyrgyzstan, Mongolia. Pakistan

V has made its way along the silk road.  
S is pushing northwards into V territory.

200CE

China, Mongolia

V has reached the Yellow Sea and is spreading.

300CE

Myanmar

V has reached Myanmar from Sri Lanka

400CE

China

Chinese V has changed to M

430CE

Thailand

M has reached Thailand and is spreading quickly northwards.

450CE

Thailand, Malaysia

M has spread southbound.

460CE

Afghanistan

V collapses west of Mongolia

475CE

Malaysia, Indonesia, Singapore

M has reached Indonesia and Singapore

500CE

North India

S has a offshoot on the border with M, forming T (Tantrayana)

560CE

Japan

M reaches Japan

600CE

North India

T rapidly takes S territory in nothern India

700CE

Tibet, Nepal

T takes land in Tibet and Nepal

760CE

West India

S collapses and ceases to be

800CE

China

T reaches Tang Dyanasty (East China), spreads southwards

1000CE

Mongolia

V collapses in Mongolia

1200CE

North India

M collapses in North India

Go to:

[https://secondary.understandingfaith.edu.au/world-religions/03/19/](https://secondary.understandingfaith.edu.au/world-religions/03/19/) Read the page and then move on to the next page in order to make notes on the following:

What is Theravada Buddhism?

Theravada Buddhists, those who follow the 'Way of the Elders', believe that their interpretation of beliefs and practices is according to the original spirit of the Buddha, and in the manner of the early Elders. The Pali Canon is their sacred text. This Buddhist school is considered the conservative and sometimes orthodox expression of Buddhism.

Theravada Buddhism is predominately found in the south of Asia - Sri Lanka, Burma, Cambodia, Laos and Thailand.

Adherents of this School aim to become arhats, gaining perfect enlightenment and thus avoiding rebirth. Their focus is religious, monastic and world-renouncing. Theravada Buddhism holds that one has to be a 'renouncer' to achieve enlightenment and therefore, salvation.

What is Mahayana Buddhism?

Mahayana Buddhism began in the first century CE. It is a more liberal form of Buddhism and umbrella organisation for various Buddhist schools, Tendai, Nichiren and Ch'an or Zen. Mahayana is available to everyone. It is mainly located in northern Asia as well as the Far East.

Mahayana Buddhists accept the Pali Canon, as well as other writings such as the Sutras. Their purpose in life is not to achieve the perfection of Enlightenment or Nirvana, but to become boddhisatvas. Mahayana Buddhists teach that enlightenment can be achieved by lay people, even in a single lifetime. The Zen, Nichiren and Pure Land groups are divisions of the Mahayana School.

In Mahayana Buddhism there is a role for religious rituals, however, this differs between the various divisions.
